result.markdown:
--- title: "Welcome Aboard üôå" subtitle: "MATH/COSC 3570 Introduction to Data Science" author: "Dr. Cheng-Han Yu
Department of Mathematical and Statistical Sciences
Marquette University" # date: "January 13 2025" # macros: _macros.tex # import a list of TeX/LaTeX definitions format: revealjs: html-math-method: method: mathjax url: "https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js" # include-in-header: # - "macros.tex" highlight-style: github code-block-bg: true self-contained: false slide-number: c/t incremental: false width: 1800 height: 1000 margin: 0.05 logo: "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e8/Marquette_Golden_Eagles_logo.svg" footer: "[math3570-s25.github.io/website](https://math3570-s25.github.io/website/)" theme: ["simple", "slides.scss"] echo: false multiplex: true code-link: true fig-cap-location: bottom fig-align: center transition: none ## fade slide convex concave zoom code-line-numbers: false title-slide-attributes: data-background-color: "#447099" # data-background-image: images/paper-texture.jpg # data-background-size: cover # data-background-color: "#698ED5" editor: source execute: freeze: true --- # {visibility="hidden"} \def\bx{\mathbf{x}} \def\bg{\mathbf{g}} \def\bw{\mathbf{w}} \def\bbeta{\boldsymbol \beta} \def\bX{\mathbf{X}} \def\by{\mathbf{y}} \def\bH{\mathbf{H}} \def\bI{\mathbf{I}} \def\bS{\mathbf{S}} \def\bW{\mathbf{W}} \def\T{\text{T}} \def\cov{\mathrm{Cov}} \def\cor{\mathrm{Corr}} \def\var{\mathrm{Var}} \def\E{\mathrm{E}} \def\bmu{\boldsymbol \mu} \DeclareMathOperator*{\argmin}{arg\,min} \def\Trace{\text{Trace}} # Taipei, Taiwan {background-image="images/01-syllabus/taiwan.jpeg" background-size="cover" background-position="50% 50%" background-color="#447099"} ::: {.absolute bottom="50" right="10"} ![](images/01-syllabus/taiwan.svg){width="500" fig-alt="Taiwan location"} ::: ::: notes - Hello everyone, how are you? I hope you have a great winter break. Welcome to 3570 Introduction to Data Science course. I am your instructor Cheng-Han Yu. - First thing first. Get to know each other. Let me first introduce my self. I was born and grew up in Taipei, Taiwan, my home country, which is a island right next to China. Taipei is a big city in terms of population. It is about the same population size as Chicago. This building is called Taipei 101, which is the tallest building in Taiwan. ::: ## My Journey {background-image="images/01-syllabus/sample_gate.png" background-size="cover" background-position="50% 50%" background-opacity="0.3"} - Assistant Professor (2020/08 - ) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/mu.svg){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - Postdoctoral Fellow ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/rice.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - PhD in Statistics ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/ucsc.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - MA in Economics/PhD program in Statistics ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/iub.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: ::: notes After college, working and doing military service for several years, I came to the US for my PhD degree. Originally I would like to study economics, but then I switched my major to statistics. - I got my master degree in economics from Indiana University Bloomington, then I transferred to UC Santa Cruz to finish my PhD studies. - Then I spent two years doing my postdoctoral research at Rice University in Houston, Texas. - Finally, in fall 2020, I came to Marquette as an assistant professor. - Midwest/Indiana-West/California-South/Texas-Midwest/Wisconsin - Been to any one of these universities/cities? - The most beautiful campus. - Who are international students? I can totally understand how hard studying and living in another country. Feel free to share your stories or difficulties, and I am more than happy to help you if you have any questions. - Poor listening and speaking skills. I was shy. - OK so, this is my background. How about you introducing yourself as well. You can share anything, your major, hobbies, your favorite food, what do you want to do after graduation, anything, - I have the class list. I'd like to learn your face and remember your name. You know, you all wear a mask. It's hard to recognize you and connect your name and your face. - When I call your name, you can say something about yourself. No need to be long, couple of seconds are good. ::: ## How to Reach Me - Office hours **TuTh 4:50 - 5:50 PM** and **Wed 12 - 1 PM** in **Cudahy Hall 353**. - üìß + Answer your question within 24 hours. + Expect a reply on **Monday** if shoot me a message **on weekends**. + Start your subject line with **[math3570]** or **[cosc3570]** followed by a **clear description of your question**. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/3570_email.png){fig-align='center' width=45%} ::: ::: + I will **NOT** reply your e-mail if ... **Check the email policy in the [syllabus](https://math3570-s25.github.io/website/course-syllabus.html)**! ## When You Have Two Dr. Yu in One Semester üòÇ {visibility="hidden"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/email_example_student.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/email_example.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: notes - This is a real case happened last semester. A student of my class sent her homework of another class linear systems to me because the instructor of that course also has last name Yu, and she messed up. So if you remember to add course number in the subject line, it will greatly reduce the possibility of sending a wrong message. And it will save your time and my time, and so we all can work more efficiently. Right? ::: ## TA Information ::::: {.columns} :::: {.column width="50%"} - Statistics PhD student **Qishi Zhan** - üì® - Help desk hours: To be announced. - Welcome to set up a meeting with your TA via Teams. - Let me know if you need any other help! üòÑ :::: :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/qishi.jpeg){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: :::: ::::: ## What is This Course? - **Every** *aspect of doing a practical data science project, from importing data to deploying what we learn from data*. . . . ‚ùì **What are prerequisites?** üëâ COSC 1010 (Intro Programming) and MATH 4720 (Intro Stats) or MATH 2780 (Intro Regression)
. . . ‚ùì **Is this like another intro stats course?** üëâ No. Statistics and data science are closely related. . . . Nowadays üëâ Data science is a *broader* subject than statistics. . . . üëâ Statistics focuses more on *analyzing and learning from data*, a part of the entire workflow of data science.
. . . ‚ùì **Is this like another intro CS or programming course?** üëâ Absolutely not. We learn how to **code for doing data science**, not for understanding computer systems and structures. ::: notes - Of course we will not cover every detail form A to Z of DS in one semester becuase DS is such a huge subject, just like computer science. It's impossible to learn CS in one semester by just taking intro to CS, right? So we'll just learn the basic and essential concepts and tools used is DS. ::: ## What is NOT Covered in This Course - **Advanced data analytics and computing** + MATH 4750 Statistical Computing + MATH 4760 Time Series Analysis + MATH 4780 Regression Analysis + MATH 4790 Bayesian Statistics + COSC 4600 Fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence + COSC 4610 Data Mining + COEN 4860 Introduction to Neural Networks . . . - **Big data**: We start with small, in-memory data sets. You don't know how to tackle big data unless you have experience with small data. . . . - **Database**: Learn SQL in + COSC 4800 Principles of Database Systems + INSY 4052 Database Management Systems. ::: notes - We won't talk about topics like cloud computing, parallel computing, distributed computing. - **Big data techniques**: As a beginner, we focus on small, in-memory datasets. You can't tackle big data unless you have experience with small data. ::: ## What Computing Languages? ::::: {.columns} :::: {.column width="50%"} ~ 60% ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/Rlogo.png){fig-align='center' width=50%} ::: ::: :::: :::: {.column width="50%"} ~ 40% ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c3/Python-logo-notext.svg){fig-align='center' width=45%} ::: ::: :::: ::::: - You've learned Python in COSC 1010. Being R-Python bilingual is getting more important! . . . üëâ Wouldn't it be great to add both languages to your resume! üòé . . . ‚ùå Don't want to learn *R and/or Python*? Take 3570 *next* semester~! ‚ùå Drop deadline: **01/21 (Tue), 11:59 PM**. ## Where to Code? [Posit Cloud](https://posit.cloud/) :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/03-posit/posit.png){fig-align='center' width=60%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"}
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/03-posit/rstudio-logo.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/38/Jupyter_logo.svg){fig-align='center' width=50%} ::: ::: ::: :::: - Have nice computing power and interactive collaboration with me and your teammates! - **Student** plan: \$5/month (Cheaper than buying a textbook!) ## Course Materials - Course Website - ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/website_s25.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://math3570-s25.github.io/website/) ::: ::: ## :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="30%"} [*Python for Data Analysis, 3E*](https://wesmckinney.com/book/) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/py4ds_book.jpg){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://wesmckinney.com/book/) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [*R for Data Science 2nd edition*](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/r4ds_book2.jpeg){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [*Tidy Modeling with R*](https://www.tmwr.org/) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/tmwr_book.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://www.tmwr.org/) ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Learning Management System ([D2L](https://d2l.mu.edu/d2l/home/545777)) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/d2l_s25.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: - **Assessments > Grades** ## Grading Policy ✨ + **30%** In-class lab exercises and participation. + **30%** Homework + **15%** Midterm mini project + **25%** Final project competition + *Extra credit opportunities* - ‚ùå You have to participate in the final presentation in order to pass the course. - ‚ùå You will **NOT** be allowed to do any extra credit projects/homework/exam to compensate for a poor grade. ## Grade-Percentage Conversion - $[x, y)$ means greater than or equal to $x$ and less than $y$. For example, 94.0 is in [94, 100] and the grade is A and 93.8 is in [90, 94) and the grade is A-. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Grade Percentage
A [94, 100]
A- [90, 94)
B+ [87, 90)
B [84, 87)
B- [80, 84)
C+ [77, 80)
C [74, 77)
C- [70, 74)
D+ [65, 70)
D [60, 65)
F [0, 60)
````` ::: ::: ## Lab Exercises (30%) - Graded as **Complete/Incomplete** and used as evidence of attendance and participation. - Allowed to have **one** incomplete lab exercise without any penalty. - Beyond that, **2%** grade percentage will be taken off for each missing/incomplete exercise. - You will create a RStudio project in [Posit Cloud](https://posit.cloud) saving all of your lab exercises. (We'll go through know-how together) ## Homework (30%) - The homework assignments are individual. Submit your own work. - ‚ùå **You may not share answers/code with your classmates**. . . . - Homework will be assigned through [**GitHub**](https://github.com/): + clone/pull the homework repo into Posit Cloud + work on the [Quarto](https://quarto.org/) file in the repo (We'll go through know-how together) . . . - You will have **at least one week** to complete your assignment. - ‚ùå **No make-up homework** for any reason unless you have [excused absence](https://bulletin.marquette.edu/policies/attendance/undergraduate/). üôè ## Mini Project (15%) - You will be team up to do the midterm mini project. - More details about the mini project presentation will be released later. ## Project (25%) - You will be team up to do the final project. - Your project can be in either of the following categories: 1. **Data analysis** using statistical models or machine learning algorithms 2. Introduce a **R or Python package** not learned in class, including **live demo** 3. Introduce a **data science tool (visualization, computing, etc)** not learned in class, including **live demo** 4. Introduce a **programming language** not learned in class for doing data science, including **live demo**, Julia, SQL, MATLAB, SAS for example. 5. **Web development**: Shiny website or dashboard, including **live demo** - The final project presentation is on **Thursday, 5/1, 2 PM** and **Monday, 5/5, 10:30 AM - 12:30 PM**. - More information will be released later. ## Generative AI and Sharing/Reusing Code Policy :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="80%"} ### Generative AI - You may use generative AI tools such as ChatGPT or DALL-E to generate a first draft of text for your work, provided that this use is *documented and cited*. [Example] Data science is an interdisciplinary field that ... [^1] [^1]: ChatGPT, response to *‚ÄúTell me what data science is,‚Äù* Jan 14, 2025, https://chat.openai.com. ::: ::: {.column width="20%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/01-syllabus/genai.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ::: :::: . . . ### Sharing/Reusing Code - Unless explicitly stated otherwise, you may make use of any online resources, but you must **explicitly cite** where you obtained any code you directly use or use as inspiration in your solutions. [Example] - The code is modified from the GitHub repo - The code is generated from ChatGPT response to *‚ÄúPlease generate Python code for solving the math problem I attach,‚Äù* Jan 14, 2025. ::: notes - You are responsible for the content of all work submitted for this course. - You can use any code shared online or in books. But please give the authors full credits. Cite their work and let me know whose code you are using to do your homework and project. - I encourage you to write your own code. This way you learn the most. - ‚ùå Any recycled code that is discovered and is not explicitly cited will be treated as plagiarism, regardless of source. üò± ::: ## Academic Integrity This course expects all students to follow University and College statements on [academic integrity](https://bulletin.marquette.edu/undergrad/academicregulations/). - **Honor Pledge and Honor Code**: *I recognize the importance of personal integrity in all aspects of life and work. I commit myself to truthfulness, honor, and responsibility, by which I earn the respect of others. I support the development of good character, and commit myself to uphold the highest standards of academic integrity as an important aspect of personal integrity. My commitment obliges me to conduct myself according to the Marquette University Honor Code*. ## [COVID-19](https://www.marquette.edu/coronavirus/) {visibility="hidden"} _It is **your** responsibility as a Marquette University student to protect the health and safety of our community in this course. The University has mandated vaccination for all students for the academic year 2021-2022. COVID Cheq will still be used, but those fully vaccinated that provide documentation will no longer receive the daily symptom screening survey. Instead, they will receive a daily email providing a green check. You may be required to show your automated green check to show clearance for entry into campus buildings. If you are experiencing symptoms related to COVID-19, you must follow the link in the automated email to report symptoms. _ - Visit [What to do if you are exposed to COVID-19 or test positive](https://www.marquette.edu/coronavirus/what-to-do-if-you-are-exposed-or-test-positive.php) website for university guidelines on the best course of action. - Visit guidance on Spring 2022 [Class attendance, withdrawal, and grading](https://www.marquette.edu/central/registrar/faculty-staff/guidance-on-fall-2021-class-attendance-withdrawal-grading.php) + Students are responsible for contacting instructors **prior** to the missed class session to indicate absence and the need to make up classwork/assignments. + Students requesting make up classwork/assignments are required to provide the **COVID Cheq "stop sign"** to confirm inability to attend class. ## Q & A ‚ùì **K: I hope to learn more about programming. R: I‚Äôm looking forward to learning more about what data science consists of rather than just learning a programming language.** üëâ To make sure everyone is on the same page, first couple of weeks is about learning R and Python syntax. After spring break, we focus on modeling and machine learning methods.
. . . ‚ùì **What do you think will be the most interesting part of the course?** üëâ I love data visualization and web development.
. . . ‚ùì **D: Do I need good coding skills to be able to succeed?** **G: How much of this class is about coding?** üëâ We'll learn *basic* syntax for doing data science step by step.
. . . ‚ùì **What kind of time estimate do you believe most students should spend on reading + assignments for the course?** üëâ Everyone is different. The more the better. ## Q & A ‚ùì **What kind of projects will we be doing for this course?** üëâ Any project related to data works. You propose one to me. We discuss it, then decide.
. . . ‚ùì **Will this class help me better understand how to code proficiently?** üëâ As you learn to speak a foreign language, you need to code a lot, frequently and constantly in order to be proficient in any programming language. No shortcut.
. . . ‚ùì **Do you know of any internships or research positions offered through Marquette University that incorporate the skills learned in this Data Science course?** üëâ Quite many. Northwestern Mutual, Direct Supply, for example. I'll share intern info with you if I get any. . . .
‚ùì **More questions** [Bring your laptop next time!]{.r-fit-text .fragment style="color: #EE6331;"}

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
